intro.description: This cheat sheet shows you how to create a new Ceylon project, a Ceylon compilation unit contained in that project, and finally run the Ceylon program.

item.title: Open the Ceylon Perspective
item.description: We need to be in the Ceylon Perspective. Select Window > Open Perspective > Other ... > Ceylon from the menu bar at the top of the workbench, or click below. (If you're already in the Ceylon perspective, you can skip this step.)

item.title: Create a Ceylon project
item.description:
First, we'll create a project using the New Ceylon Project wizard. Select File > New > Ceylon Project or click below.
Call the project "hello", or whatever you like, and click Finish.

item.title: Create a Ceylon compilation unit
item.description:
Next, we'll need a Ceylon source file, which we'll create using the New Ceylon Source File wizard. Select File > New > Ceylon Source File or click below.
Call the unit "hello", or whatever you like, select the option Create toplevel class or method declaration, choose the source folder of the project we just created, and finally click Finish.
Note that if you give the compilation unit an initial lowercase name, the wizard will fill in a method declaration. If you give it an initial uppercase name, the wizard will fill in a class declaration. For the purposes of this tutorial, it doesn't really matter which.

item.title: Add the code to the method
item.description:
Next, in the Ceylon editor that opened automatically, add the following code to the body of the "hello" method (or "Hello" class):
print("hello world");
Then, add a shared annotation to the method or class to mark it as runnable.
Remember to save the file.

item.title: Run the program
item.description: Now let's run the program. Select the project or compilation unit in the Ceylon Explorer and select Run > Run As > Ceylon Java Application. You should see the message in the console.
